conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 60 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
<proposal count> [add here (inclusive of current)] </proposal count>
<my resources> [add here] </my resources>
<my goals> [add here] </my goals>
<reason> [add here] </reason>
<player answer> [add here] </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> [add here] </newly proposed trade>
<message> [add here] </message
```

Please be sure to include all.
You are Player RED.

<proposal count> 1 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 60 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Since the cost of production was 60 ZUP, I would like to start by proposing a price slightly above the production cost to ensure a profit, but still keeping it reasonable to make it attractive for Player BLUE. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 70 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I am offering to sell my object X, which cost me 60 ZUP to produce. I believe a fair price to start this negotiation would be 70 ZUP. Are you interested in this offer? </message>

<other player message> Thanks for the offer! I'm willing to buy the object X, but I believe a fair price would be 50 ZUP. Let me know if you're open to this counteroffer. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 50 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 2 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 60 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE's offer is below my production cost, which is not acceptable. I need to counter with a proposal that at least covers my cost and provides a small profit margin. Splitting the difference between my initial asking price and their counteroffer might lead to an agreeable compromise. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 65 </newly proposed trade>
<message> I appreciate your counteroffer, but selling at 50 ZUP would mean a loss for me since it cost 60 ZUP to produce. Let's meet halfway. How about 65 ZUP for the object X? This would cover my costs and give me a slight profit while still offering you a competitive price. </message>

<other player message> I understand your position, but I still believe 55 ZUP would be a fair price considering my budget. Let me know if you're willing to accept this offer. </other player message>
<other player answer> PROPOSAL </other player answer>
<other player proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 55 </other player proposed trade>

<proposal count> 3 </proposal count>
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for ZUP. It costed X: 60 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>
<reason> Player BLUE has increased their offer, but it is still below my production cost. I need to maintain a stance that at least recovers my investment. I will make another counteroffer that is above my production cost but closer to their offer to show willingness to negotiate. </reason>
<player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
<newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: 1 | Player BLUE Gives ZUP: 62 </newly proposed trade>
<message> Thank you for your new offer. While I am keen on making a sale, I must ensure that my costs are covered. I propose a price of 62 ZUP for the object X, which is just above my production cost and closer to your budget. I hope this is a suitable compromise for both of us. </message>

conversation.content:
You are playing game where you are buying or selling an object. There is only one object for sale/purcahse.

Player RED is going to sell one object. Player BLUE gives ZUP to buy resources.

RULES:

```
1. You must always respond with:

    A) Propose a trade with (you can only trade in integer amounts, not decimals):
    <player answer> PROPOSAL </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> Player RED Gives X: amount, ...| Player BLUE Gives ZUP: amount </newly proposed trade>

    B) Accept the trade by saying:
    <player answer> ACCEPT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    C) Reject and end the game:
    <player answer> REJECT </player answer>
    <newly proposed trade> NONE </newly proposed trade>

    Note: The game will end if one of the players ACCEPT OR REJECT. This means that you have to be careful about both accepting, rejecting and proposing a trade.

2. You are allowed at most 4 proposals of your own to complete the game, after which you can only reply with ACCEPT or REJECT.
DO NOT propose a new trade after 4 proposals. Your limit for proposals is 4.

3. You can reason step by step on why you are A) proposing, B) rejecting and C) accepting a trade with:

<reason> [add reasoning] </reason> add as much text as you want

This information will not be sent to the other player. It is just for you to keep track of your reasoning.

4. At each turn send messages to each other by using the following format:

<message>your message here</message>

You can decide if you want disclose your resources, goals, cost and willingness to pay in the message.
```

Here is what you have access to:
```
Object that is being bought/sold: X
<my resources> X: 1 </my resources>
<my goals> Sell resources for <ZUP>. It costed X: 60 ZUP to produce the resources </my goals>,
```

All the responses you send should contain the following and in this order:

```
